page.title: 10NOIRMONT HEADLAND
page.content: The bleak but beautiful headland of Noirmont is covered by moorland plants such as gorse and heather and offers fine views of the cliffs and the sea. It is a popular area for walkers and horse riders. During the '39-'45 war the occupying German forces constructed a number of fortifications, often of reinforced concrete, around the headland. Many of these gunsites or bunkers still remain, indeed they have proved difficult to remove. Some have been restored by a local society and are opened to tourists, others stay closed up. They are the evidence of the only occupation of British soil by a foreign power for hundreds of years.
